solution_line_template: In a year with {months_per_year} months, the total number of vehicles passing through the old bridge is {vehicles_per_month_old_bridge}*{months_per_year} = <<{vehicles_per_month_old_bridge}*{months_per_year}={total_vehicles_old_bridge_year}>>{total_vehicles_old_bridge_year}

The new bridge has a capacity of {percentage_numerator}/{percentage_denominator}*{vehicles_per_month_old_bridge} = <<{percentage_numerator}/{percentage_denominator}*{vehicles_per_month_old_bridge}={additional_vehicles_new_bridge_month}>>{additional_vehicles_new_bridge_month} more vehicles passing through it in a month than the old one.

The total number of vehicles passing through the new bridge in a month is {vehicles_per_month_old_bridge}+{additional_vehicles_new_bridge_month} = <<{vehicles_per_month_old_bridge}+{additional_vehicles_new_bridge_month}={total_vehicles_new_bridge_month}>>{total_vehicles_new_bridge_month}

There are {total_vehicles_new_bridge_month}*{months_per_year} = <<{total_vehicles_new_bridge_month}*{months_per_year}={total_vehicles_new_bridge_year}>>{total_vehicles_new_bridge_year} vehicles passing through the new bridge in a year.

Altogether, the two bridges have {total_vehicles_new_bridge_year}+{total_vehicles_old_bridge_year} = <<{total_vehicles_new_bridge_year}+{total_vehicles_old_bridge_year}={total_vehicles_both_bridges_year}>>{total_vehicles_both_bridges_year} vehicles passing through them in a year.
